title: How to Label a Chart

steps.headline: Open a Word 2003 file.
steps.description: Do this by locating the file in your folders and double-clicking on it. If you want to open a new Word 2003 file instead of work on an existing one, just double-click the Word 2003 program icon on your desktop instead.

steps.headline: Insert an object.
steps.description: On the top portion of your window, you will see the Menu bar. Click the “Insert” button. Click “Object,” and then click the “Create New” tab when the pop-up window appears.

steps.headline: Create a new graph chart.
steps.description:
Click “Microsoft Graph Chart” in the Object Type box, and click “OK.”
A separate Excel window should open showing you the data sheet for the graph. You will be able to change the values shown in the chart by changing the values in the cells of this data sheet.

steps.headline: Label the chart elements.
steps.description: The leftmost column and top row of the chart spreadsheet will be for the names of the chart elements. Change these to your liking. You will have then labelled the chart; the changes here will reflect in the Word document.

steps.headline: Name the chart.
steps.description: Do this by clicking on the “Name of the chart” field, which is likely to be “Chart Title” by default. Once clicked, the text box can be edited, where you can type the name you want to give the chart.

steps.headline: Open a Word 2007–2010 file.
steps.description: Do this by locating the file in your folders and double-clicking on it. If you want to open a new Word 2007–2010 file instead of work on an existing one, just double-click the Word 2007–2010 program icon on your desktop instead.

steps.headline: Click the Insert menu.
steps.description: The ribbon tabs at the top of the screen should change its contents.

steps.headline: Insert a chart.
steps.description: Under Illustrations in the ribbon, click on “Chart,” and the Insert Chart box will appear, allowing you to choose a chart style.

steps.headline: Select a chart style.
steps.description: Just go over the options and select one. Once you've clicked a chart style you want, press “OK” at the bottom right corner. The chart will appear, along with the data sheet it is associated with.

steps.headline: Label the chart elements.
steps.description: Do this by entering a name on the leftmost column and top row for each column.

steps.headline: Name the chart.
steps.description: Do this by clicking on the default “Chart Title” field. Once clicked, the text box can be edited, where you can type the name you want to give it.

steps.headline: Open a Word 2013 file.
steps.description: Do this by locating the file in your folders and double-clicking on it. If you want to open a new Word 2013 file instead of work on an existing one, just double-click the Word 2013 program icon on your desktop instead.

steps.headline: Click the Insert menu.
steps.description: The ribbon tabs at the top of the screen should change its contents.

steps.headline: Insert a chart.
steps.description: Under Illustrations in the ribbon, choose “Chart” at to the right of SmartArt.

steps.headline: Select a chart style.
steps.description: Choose a chart style and click “OK” on the bottom right. The chart will appear, along with the data sheet it is associated with.

steps.headline: Label the chart elements.
steps.description: In the Excel sheet designated to the chart, you can enter the names for each segment by typing them on the leftmost column and topmost row of the sheet.

steps.headline: Name the chart.
steps.description: Do this by clicking on the default “Chart Title” field. Once clicked, the text box can be edited, where you can type the name you want to give it.

steps.headline: Open a Powerpoint 2003 file.
steps.description: Do this by locating the file in your folders and double-clicking on it. If you want to open a new Powerpoint 2003 file instead of work on an existing one, just double-click the Powerpoint 2003 program icon on your desktop instead.

steps.headline: Insert a chart.
steps.description:
Click “Insert” from the menu bar at the top then click “Chart.”
The chart should appear, along with the Excel sheet for the chart.

steps.headline: Add values.
steps.description: Enter the values you want to assign for each segment in the rows and columns provided.

steps.headline: Label the chart.
steps.description: In the leftmost column and top row, enter the names you wish to assign to the segments.

steps.headline: Name the chart.
steps.description: Do this by clicking on the default “Chart Title” field. Once clicked, the text box can be edited, where you can type the name you want to give it.

steps.headline: Open a Powerpoint 2007–2010 file.
steps.description: Do this by locating the file in your folders and double-clicking on it. If you want to open a new Powerpoint 2007–2010 file instead of work on an existing one, just double-click the Powerpoint 2007–2010 program icon on your desktop instead.

steps.headline: Insert chart.
steps.description: Under Illustrations along the ribbon tabs at the top, click on “Chart.” An Insert Chart box will appear, allowing you to choose a chart style.

steps.headline: Select a chart style.
steps.description: Go through the options, and once you've clicked a chart style you want, press “OK.” The chart will appear, along with the Excel data sheet it is associated with.

steps.headline: Add values.
steps.description: In the spreadsheet, enter the data you wish to assign to the segments by entering them on the cells.

steps.headline: Label the chart.
steps.description: Now, you can name the segments by entering the names on the leftmost column and top row. The changes here will reflect in the Powerpoint 2007–2010 file.

steps.headline: Name the chart.
steps.description: Do this by clicking on the default “Chart Title” field. Once clicked, the text box can be edited, where you can type the name you want to give it.

steps.headline: Open a Powerpoint 2013 file.
steps.description: Do this by locating the file in your folders and double-clicking on it. If you want to open a new Powerpoint 2013 file instead of work on an existing one, just double-click the Powerpoint 2013 program icon on your desktop instead.

steps.headline: Click on “Insert” in the menu bar at the top.
steps.description: The ribbon tabs will change to show you insert options.

steps.headline: Insert a chart.
steps.description: Under Illustrations in the ribbon, choose “Chart” to the right of SmartArt.

steps.headline: Choose a chart style.
steps.description: Go through the options, select one, and click “OK.”

steps.headline: Add values.
steps.description: The chart will come with its own Excel spreadsheet, where you can enter the values for each segment by typing them on the cells.

steps.headline: Label the chart.
steps.description: To label the chart segments, type the names in the leftmost column and top row of the chart's Excel spreadsheet.

steps.headline: Name the chart.
steps.description: Do this by clicking on the default “Chart Title” field. Once clicked, the text box can be edited, where you can type the name you want to give it.

methods.name: Labelling a Chart in Excel 2007, 2010, and 2013

steps.headline: Open file from these programs that you will work on.
steps.description: Do this by locating the file in your folders and double-clicking on it. If you want to open a new file instead of work on an existing one, just double-click the Excel program icon on your desktop instead.

steps.headline: Highlight the cells you want to create a chart for.
steps.description: Do this by clicking and dragging your mouse to include the cells you want. Their values will incorporate directly into the chart you will insert.

steps.headline: Insert chart.
steps.description: Clicking on “Insert” in the menu bar at the top will bring up more insert options. The ribbon tabs will have a “Charts group,” where you can choose what style of chart you want.

steps.headline: Select a chart style.
steps.description: Click on a chart style icon, and an expanded menu will appear, allowing you to get more detailed choices for the chart you want to insert. Click on a chart you want and it will add the chart.

steps.headline: Label the chart.
steps.description: The chart hinges on the values of the cells you highlighted before creating a chart. To change the element labels of the chart, all you have to do is to change the name in the cells themselves.

steps.headline: Name the chart.
steps.description: Do this by clicking on the default “Chart Title” field. Once clicked, the text box can be edited, where you can type the name you want to give it.

methods.name: Labelling a Chart Using Google Sheets

steps.headline: Go to Google Drive.
steps.description: Open your favorite web browser and head to https://drive.google.com.

steps.headline: Sign in.
steps.description: Click the blue “Sign In” button in the upper right corner of your browser screen. Type your Google account login details in the appropriate to access Google Drive. If you do not have a Google account yet, sign up here: https://accounts.google.com/SignUp.

steps.headline: Create a new Google Sheet.
steps.description: Once you're in Google Drive, you will be able to create a new Sheet document by clicking on the red “NEW” button on the left panel. An expanded menu will come up, and you can choose Google Sheets by clicking on the green “Sheets” icon below the blue “Document” icon.

steps.headline: Add values.
steps.description: Enter the data you want to use for the chart into the cells of the spreadsheet.

steps.headline: Highlight the values.
steps.description: Once all the data you want is entered, select the data you want by Shift+clicking on the array of ranges you want to use for the chart.

steps.headline: Create chart.
steps.description: Click on the “Insert” button in the menu bar at the top. Go down and look for “Chart,” with a bar graph icon, and click on it. A pop-up window will appear, allowing you to create your chart. The selected data will be shown under the Start tab.

steps.headline: Edit ranges.
steps.description: You can add more ranges by clicking “Add another range,” or change the range by clicking “Select range.”

steps.headline: Choose a chart style.
steps.description: Clicking on the “Charts” tab will let you select a chart style, but annotations (which you will use to label) are limited to line and area charts only.

steps.headline: Name the chart.
steps.description: Click “Customize” to enter a chart title as well as configure the font.

steps.headline: Insert chart.
steps.description: Click on “Insert” when you are finished.

steps.headline: Label the chart.
steps.description: To add labels to the chart, enter the annotations at the column to the right of each data point you want to label. The annotations should appear on the chart as you type them.
